concepts.unlisted_description: Reference to High Court by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case the receipts from the sale of sal trees can be said to be agricultural income under section 2 1 and exempt from taxation under section 4 3 viii of the Income-tax Ac ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case the receipts from the sale of sal trees can be said to be agricultural income under section 2 1  and exempt from taxation under section 4 3  viii  of the Income-tax Ac ?

issues.text: whether the operations which the assessees claim to have performed in these forests were agricultural operations such as to bring the income derived from these forests within the definition of agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: We shall however proceed on the basis that these facts were proved by the assessees and determine whether the operations which the assessees claim to have performed in these forests were agricultural operations such as to bring the income derived

arguments.claim: Receipts from the sale of sal trees from forests of spontaneous growth are agricultural income exempt under sections 2(1) and 4(3)(viii) because human skill and labour were employed in maintenance, preservation, nursing, improving and rearing of the forests through various forestry operations.

anchor.surface_text: We shall however proceed on the basis that these facts were proved by the assessees and determine whether the operations which the assessees claim to have performed in these forests were agricultural operations such as to bring the income derived from these forests within the definition of agricultural income.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed untouched and in the production of the income the assessees had made numbercontribution by way of cultivation. There were numberbasic operations ei

arguments.court_reasoning: No basic operations like tilling or sowing; only subsequent forestry operations insufficient per principles in CIT v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy.

arguments.claim: Receipts from forests were agricultural income as held by Assistant Commissioner in 1923 order, and Income-tax authorities accepted and ceased assessment for years.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax on appeal held by his order dated April 28, 1923, that receipts from forests were agricultural income and the Income-tax authorities accepted the said decision and ceased to assess such receipts for a good number of years.

arguments.claim: Even without tilling or planting, forestry operations are conducive to growth, involve human skill on land, making them agricultural operations and land used for agricultural purposes.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the majority of the Judges held that even though there was no tilling of the land or planting of seeds or saplings and the trees were of spontaneous germination, the operations carried on by the assessees were conducive to the growth and development of the trees and in essence involved the expenditure of human skill and labour on the land itself.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed untouched and in the production of the income the assessees had made numbercontribution by way of cultivation. There were numberbasic operations ei

arguments.court_reasoning: Erroneous ratio; requires basic operations on land; forestry operations are only subsequent.

arguments.claim: No evidence to support claims of operations; affidavit statements unreliable without means to test.

anchor.surface_text: Even though Sarjoo Prasad, C.J., and Ram Labhaya, J., proceeded on the basis that these facts were proved, Deka, J., struck a dissenting note and observed that there was no evidence as to the claim made by the respondents and that the statements made on affidavit could not be accepted as there was no means to test them.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hat these facts were proved by the assessees and determine whether the operations which the assessees claim to have performed in these forests were ag

arguments.court_reasoning: SC proceeds assuming facts proved but rejects substantive claim.

arguments.claim: Expenses on forest operations insignificant compared to gross receipts (e.g., 8% Mechpara, 4% Parbatjoar), indicating not substantial human contribution akin to agriculture.

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted that on the question of the employment of human skill and labour, the appellants representative stated before the Tribunal that with regard to the Mechpara Estate, the expenses on forests establishment including temporary hands were estimated at Rs. 15,000 a year, the gross receipts being about Rs. 1,70,000.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: yvert the whole of them into agricultural operations. We are of opinion that the ratio adopted by the majority of the judges of the High Court was err

arguments.court_reasoning: Fortifies conclusion that operations insignificant and not basic agriculture.

arguments.claim: Income from sale of spontaneously grown trees not agricultural under section 2(1) as no basic operations (tilling, sowing, planting); only subsequent operations (preservation etc.) insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: The connotation of the terms agriculture and agricultural purpose and the conditions under which the forestry operations performed by the assessee on forests of spontaneous growth can be assimilated to agricultural operations so as to constitute the income derived from the sale of the forest trees agricultural income within the meaning of its definition in section 2 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act have been laid down by us in the judgment just delivered in Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy.

arguments.claim: Forestry operations listed (reservation, marking, creeper cutting etc.) do not constitute basic agricultural operations; cannot be tacked to convert into agriculture without basics.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles which we have enunciated in that judgment to the facts of the instant cases, it appears that there was no planting or sowing of the seeds no was any human agency employed for the purpose of tilling the soil.

holdings.text: Applying the principles which we have enunciated in that judgment to the facts of the instant cases, it appears that there was no planting or sowing of the seeds nor was any human agency employed for the purpose of tilling the soil. The soil had remained untouched and in the production of the income the assessees had made no contribution by way of cultivation. There were no basic operations either which were performed by the assessees on the forest lands.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles which we have enunciated in that judgment to the facts of the instant cases, it appears that there was no planting or sowing of the seeds nor was any human agency employed for the purpose of tilling the soil. The soil had remained untouched and in the production of the income the assessees had made no contribution by way of cultivation. There were no basic operations either which were performed by the assessees on the forest lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly applies principles from companion judgment CIT v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy defining agricultural operations as requiring basic operations on land; finds none here, only subsequent operations after sprouting.

holdings.text: What was done by them was the performance of forestry operations which were in the nature of subsequent operations, operations which were performed after the produce had sprouted form the soil. [...] Even though these subsequent operations had the effect of increasing the produce of the forests, the forests nevertheless remained forests of spontaneous growth.

anchor.surface_text: What was done by them was the performance of forestry operations which were in the nature of subsequent operations, operations which were performed after the produce had sprouted form the soil. The forests continued to be forests of spontaneous growth and the only result of the performance of these operations on the produce of the forests which was the outcome of spontaneous growth unaided by human skill and labour was the maintenance, preservation, nursing, improving and rearing of the forests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classifies listed forestry operations (marking, thinning, fire protection etc.) as subsequent operations only; spontaneous growth persists despite them.

holdings.text: None of the operations was assimilated to basic operations in agriculture and unless and until there was even one basic operation on the land itself the rest of the operations could not be tacked on to them so as to convert the whole of them into agricultural operations.

anchor.surface_text: The various operations which were described in the statements of case were no doubt for fostering the growth of the forests and obtain the greatest advantage from the forest trees, but they nevertheless were of spontaneous growth. Nothing was done by the assessees to grow the trees from the soil itself. They had grown there by the process of nature. The obstacles which would retard the growth of these trees which had grown spontaneously from the soil were certainly removed but these operations would not convert these subsequent operations into basic operations which would be the only pre-requisites for the cultivation of the forest land. Out of the categories a to j set out in the statement of facts, none of the operations was assimilated to basic operations in agriculture and unless and until there was even one basic operation on the land itself the rest of the operations could not be tacked on to them so as to convert the whole of them into agricultural operations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires at least one basic operation for any tacking of subsequent operations to qualify as agriculture; none of assessees' operations qualify as basic.

holdings.text: We are of opinion that the ratio adopted by the majority of the judges of the High Court was erroneous and the referred question ought to have been answered in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the ratio adopted by the majority of the judges of the High Court was erroneous and the referred question ought to have been answered in the negative. We are fortified in this conclusion if regard be had to the fact that he forestry operations which were performed by the assessees were of insignificant value as compared with the gross receipts derived by them from the sale of the forest trees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court majority's view that human skill in forestry ops suffices without basic ops; answers referred question negatively based on Benoy Kumar principles and low expenditure ratio.

holdings.text: The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the decision reached by the majority of the Judges of the high Court was not correct and it ought to be set aside. The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative. The appellant will get from the respondents one set of costs in all the appeals in this Court and Rs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispositive order reversing High Court and answering question no, with costs to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles which we have enunciated in that judgment to the facts of the instant cases, it appears that there was no planting or sowing of the seeds nor was any human agency employed for the purpose of tilling the soil. The soil had remained untouched and in the production of the income the assessees had made no contribution by way of cultivation. There were no basic operations either which were performed by the assessees on the forest lands.

We are therefore of opinion that the decision reached by the majority of the Judges of the high Court was number companyrect and it ought to be set aside. The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative. The appellant

The various operations which were described in the statements of case were no doubt for fostering the growth of the forests and obtain the greatest advantage from the forest trees, but they nevertheless were of spontaneous growth. Nothing was done by the assessees to grow the trees from the soil itself. They had grown there by the process of nature. The obstacles which would retard the growth of these trees which had grown spontaneously from the soil were certainly removed but these operations would not convert these subsequent operations into basic operations which would be the only pre-requisites for the cultivation of the forest land. Out of the categories a to j set out in the statement of facts, none of the operations was assimilated to basic operations in agriculture and unless and until there was even one basic operation on the land itself the rest of the operations could not be tacked on to them so as to convert the whole of them into agricultural operations.
